questions.text: A 78-year-old woman presents with exertional dyspnea, and chest pain. Echo was done and showed severe aortic stenosis, He has hypertension, chronic kidney disease (stage G4), hyperlipidemia, severe COPD, and atrial fibrillation. What is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI)

 

Option D:

 

TAVI is recommended for symptomatic patients with severe aortic stenosis who are at high or prohibitive risk for SAVR. TAVI is less invasive than SAVR and has shown similar outcomes in high-risk patients.

 

Option A. Balloon aortic valvuloplasty: Temporary solution, not recommended for definitive treatment of severe AS.

 

Option B. Continued medical therapy: Not appropriate for symptomatic severe AS, as it does not address the underlying valvular issue.

 

Option C. Surgical aortic valve replacement: High risk in this patient due to comorbidities and age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transcatheter aortic valve implantation is recommended in preference to surgical aortic valve replacement for symptomatic patients with severe aortic stenosis who are older than 80 years or younger patients with a life expectancy less than 10 years.

 

Transcatheter aortic valve implantation is recommended for symptomatic patients of any age with severe aortic stenosis and a high or prohibitive surgical risk if predicted post procedure survival is more than 12 months with an acceptable quality of life.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with progressive dyspnea on exertion and fatigue. Physical examination reveals an early diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border that increases with inspiration. ECG shows right axis deviation and right atrial enlargement. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tricuspid stenosis

 

Option C:

 

The combination of dyspnea, fatigue, early diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border that increases with inspiration, and ECG findings of right heart enlargement strongly suggests tricuspid stenosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aortic regurgitation: Presents with a diastolic murmur at the left sternal border but decreases with inspiration.

 

Option B. Mitral stenosis: Presents with a diastolic murmur at the apex and does not increase with inspiration.

 

Option D. Pulmonary regurgitation: Presents with a diastolic murmur at the left sternal border but decreases with inspiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the clinical presentation of tricuspid stenosis, including the characteristic murmur and ECG findings.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with fatigue and near-syncope with exertion. He has a 3/6 systolic ejection murmur along the right upper sternal border that increases with squatting. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bicuspid aortic valve

 

Option A:

 

A systolic ejection murmur along the right upper sternal border that increases with squatting is a classic finding of a bicuspid aortic valve (BAV). BAV is a congenital abnormality where the aortic valve has two leaflets instead of three. This can lead to aortic stenosis over time, causing symptoms like fatigue, dyspnea, and syncope with exertion. Squatting increases venous return and left ventricular volume, which accentuates the murmur in aortic stenosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM): The murmur of HCM is typically heard best at the left lower sternal border and decreases with squatting.

 

Option C. Restrictive membranous ventricular septal defect (VSD): VSDs typically present with a holosystolic murmur, not a systolic ejection murmur.

 

Option D. Ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm: This typically presents with a continuous murmur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Systolic ejection murmur along the right upper sternal border that increases with squatting as a classic finding of a bicuspid aortic valve.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy and severe secondary mitral regurgitation (MR) is on maximally tolerated guideline-directed medical therapy (GDMT) and is now asymptomatic. What is the most appropriate additional management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) No additional therapy

 

Option D:

 

In patients with secondary MR due to left ventricular (LV) dysfunction, optimal GDMT is the first-line treatment. Since the patient is asymptomatic and GDMT has effectively improved her symptoms and likely reduced the severity of MR, no further intervention is needed at this time.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging ( MRI): Unnecessary if the mechanism and severity of MR are already well-established.

 

Option B. Cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT): Indicated for patients with LVEF ≤35%, QRS duration ≥150 ms, and NYHA class II-IV symptoms despite GDMT. Not applicable here.

 

Option C. Surgical mitral valve repair: Considered if the patient remains symptomatic despite optimal GDMT or if there is progressive LV enlargement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In asymptomatic patients with severe secondary MR due to LV dysfunction, optimal GDMT is the first-line therapy and usually sufficient.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman with no medical problems presents with a diminished S1, an aortic ejection click, and a grade 2/6 early diastolic murmur at the left sternal border that is accentuated when leaning forward. What is the most appropriate diagnostic test?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE)

 

Option D:

 

TTE is the mainstay of noninvasive imaging to evaluate cardiac murmurs and assess for structural abnormalities. The findings described in this case are suggestive of aortic regurgitation, which can be readily visualized and quantified on TTE.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cardiac catheterization: Invasive and not the initial step for a new murmur.

 

Option B. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI): More expensive and not routinely used as the first-line investigation.

 

Option C. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE): More invasive than TTE and reserved for cases where TTE is inconclusive or there is a high suspicion of endocarditis or other valvular pathology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) is the initial diagnostic test of choice for evaluating a new cardiac murmur.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man presents with a 3 hour history of chest pain. His BP is 80/50 mmHg, HR is 120/min and has elevated JVP and clear lungs. ECG is shown. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intravenous 0.9% saline

 

Option C:

 

This patient is likely experiencing right ventricular (RV) infarction, a complication of inferior MI. The key features suggestive of RV infarction are hypotension, elevated central venous pressure, clear lungs, and ST-segment elevation in lead V4R. Intravenous fluids are the first-line treatment to increase RV preload and improve cardiac output.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Intra-aortic balloon pump placement: Indicated in cardiogenic shock with LV dysfunction, but not the first-line treatment for RV infarction.

 

Option B. Intravenous dobutamine: Inotrope may be considered if fluids are ineffective, but not the initial management.

 

Option D. Oral metoprolol: Beta-blockers can worsen hypotension and should be avoided in RV infarction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A patient with an inferior myocardial infarction with right ventricular involvement and hypotension should receive intravenous fluids.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with atrial fibrillation and severe primary mitral regurgitation (MR) due to mitral valve prolapse has an LVEF of 55% and LV end-systolic dimension of 60 mm. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Surgical mitral valve repair

 

Option B:

 

Surgical mitral valve repair is the first-line therapy for patients with primary severe MR who meet the criteria for intervention (symptomatic or asymptomatic with LV enlargement/dysfunction).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI): Unnecessary if the mechanism and severity of MR are already established by TTE.

 

Option C. Transcatheter mitral valve repair (TMVR): Considered in patients with favourable anatomy and high risk for surgical repair.

 

Option D. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE): May be helpful if TTE is inconclusive, but not necessary in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Surgery for chronic primary severe mitral regurgitation is indicated in the presence of symptoms, left ventricular dilation, or reduced ejection fraction.

 

Surgical mitral valve repair is first-line therapy for patients with primary severe mitral regurgitation meeting indications for intervention.

choices.text: Stop warfarin and start subcutaneous dose-adjusted unfractionated heparin (UFH)

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a mechanical mitral valve prosthesis is planning pregnancy. She is currently on warfarin 4mg with a stable INR of 3.0. What is the most appropriate anticoagulation strategy during the first trimester?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Continue warfarin

 

Option D:

 

Warfarin is the preferred anticoagulant during pregnancy for women with mechanical heart valves if the dose is 5 mg/d or less. It is the most studied anticoagulant in this population and has established safety and efficacy data.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Stop warfarin and start Bivalirudin: Not recommended for long-term anticoagulation in pregnancy.

 

Option B. Stop warfarin and start Dabigatran: Direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) are not recommended in pregnancy due to limited safety data.

 

Option C. Stop warfarin and start subcutaneous dose-adjusted unfractionated heparin UFH: Can be considered if warfarin dose is >5 mg/d or if the patient prefers to avoid warfarin during the first trimester.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warfarin is the preferred anticoagulant for pregnant women with mechanical heart valves if the dose is ≤5 mg/d.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a history of aortic valve replacement and end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis presents with progressive fatigue, fever, shortness of breath and bilateral basal crackles. ECG shows first degree AV block. Echocardiogram shows a vegetation on the aortic valve bioprosthesis with severe aortic regurgitation. After blood cultures and empiric antibiotics are initiated, what is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Early surgical aortic valve replacement

 

Option B:

 

The patient has prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE) with severe aortic regurgitation and heart failure. Early surgical valve replacement is indicated in PVE with heart failure, abscess formation, or persistent infection despite antibiotics.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cardiac catheterization: Can be done in selected patients at the time of surgery to determine the need of coronary artery bypass grafting.

 

Option C. Placement of a temporary pacemaker: Not the most important step at this point. 

 

Option D. No change in therapy: Inadequate as surgery is required for definitive management of PVE with complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early surgical valve replacement is indicated in patients with IE and heart failure, annular or aortic abscess, or destructive penetrating lesions.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with exertional dyspnea and elevated BNP. 2D Echo shows EF of 45% and low-flow, low-gradient severe aortic stenosis. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dobutamine stress echocardiography

 

Option B:

 

Dobutamine stress echocardiography is recommended to differentiate between true severe AS and pseudosevere AS (low flow due to reduced LV function).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cardiac catheterization: In this patient who likely has low cardiac output, direct measurement of the aortic valve gradient by cardiac catheterization (Option A) would result in low gradients that underestimate the severity of the AS, similar to gradient and velocity values on resting echocardiography. Dobutamine catheterization may be performed in lieu of dobutamine echocardiography in this case.

 

Option C. & option D. Surgical aortic valve replacement  (SAVR) or Transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI): Proceeding to surgical or transcatheter aortic valve implantation is inappropriate at this time; the resting echo does not adequately differentiate between pseudosevere AS due to insufficient stroke volume and low-flow, low-gradient severe AS.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diagnose low-flow, low-gradient severe symptomatic aortic stenosis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, diabetes mellitus, and severe aortic stenosis undergoes coronary angiography, revealing diffuse coronary artery disease requiring CABG. Her ascending aorta measures 5.6 cm in diameter. What additional intervention is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) AVR and aortic repair

 

Option B:

 

The patient has severe aortic stenosis requiring AVR and a significant ascending aortic aneurysm (TAA) (>4.5 cm) that should be repaired concurrently during CABG to prevent rupture.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aortic valve replacement (AVR): Does not address the TAA, which has a high risk of rupture.

 

Option C. Transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI): Contraindicated in patients with concomitant significant CAD and TAA.

 

Option D. No intervention: This would leave the patient at risk for aortic dissection or rupture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with an ascending aorta or aortic root larger than 4.5 cm in diameter who require surgery for CAD or valve pathology, aortic repair should be performed at the time of cardiac surgery.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man had a mechanical mitral valve replacement 1 year ago. He is currently on warfarin and his INR is 3.4. He now presents with easy bruising and scattered ecchymoses. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Continue current warfarin dosage

 

Option A:

 

This patient has a mechanical heart valve, requiring long-term anticoagulation with warfarin to prevent thromboembolic events. His INR is within the therapeutic range for mechanical mitral valves (2.5-3.5). Easy bruising and ecchymoses are common side effects of warfarin and do not necessarily warrant dose adjustment in the absence of significant bleeding.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Decreasing warfarin dosage: Would increase the risk of thromboembolic events.

 

Option C. Discontinue warfarin and start aspirin: Not sufficient for anticoagulation in patients with mechanical valves.

 

Option D. Discontinue warfarin and start dabigatran: DOACs are not recommended for patients with mechanical valves (based on the data from Re-ALIGN trial).

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with a prosthetic cardiac valve, the appropriate INR goal varies by type of valve and valve position, with a goal INR of 3.0 (range 2.5-3.5) for a mechanical valve in the mitral position. Dabigatran is associated with excess bleeding and thrombosis, and the safety of other direct oral anticoagulants has not been assessed.

choices.text: CT angiography of the thoracic aorta

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with exertional dyspnea and syncope has echocardiographic findings of severe aortic stenosis (AS) and a bicuspid aortic valve. What is the most next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CT angiography of the thoracic aorta

 

Bicuspid aortic valve is often associated with aortopathy, which can lead to aortic dilation or dissection. Therefore, assessing the thoracic aorta with CT angiography (or MRI) is crucial before proceeding with aortic valve intervention.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cardiac catheterization: May be needed to evaluate coronaries if intermediate to high pre-test probability. If low pre-test probability, CTA of the coronaries can be along with CTA of the aorta.

 

Option C. Exercise treadmill stress testing: C/I in symptomatic severe AS due to the risk of adverse events.

 

Option D. Transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI): Not appropriate before assessing the aorta, as aortic pathology might influence the choice of intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with bicuspid aortic valve and suspected aortic stenosis, evaluate the thoracic aorta before proceeding with any intervention.

questions.text: A 63-year-old asymptomatic man has severe aortic regurgitation (AR) with normal left ventricular (LV) ejection fraction (EF) and elevated LV end-systolic dimension (45 mm). What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Repeat evaluation in 6 months

 

In asymptomatic patients with severe AR and normal LV function, surgery is not immediately indicated unless the LV is severely enlarged (LVESD >50 mm). This patient's LVESD is 45mm, so monitoring with serial echocardiograms is appropriate.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Surgical aortic valve replacement (SAVR): Not indicated yet due to lack of symptoms and only mild LV enlargement.

 

Option C. Transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI): Not recommended for isolated severe AR in patients who are candidates for surgery.

 

Option D. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE): May be helpful if TTE image quality is poor, but not necessary in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In symptomatic patients with severe aortic regurgitation, aortic valve surgery is indicated regardless of left ventricular systolic function.

 

In asymptomatic patients with chronic severe aortic regurgitation and left ventricular systolic dysfunction (EF ≤55%), aortic valve surgery is indicated.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is evaluated for exertional dyspnea and a sensation of pounding in the neck that has progressed over the last year. Blood pressure is 150/60 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 60/min. The following murmur is heard over the left sternal edge. Identify the cause.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aortic regurgitation

 

Option A:

 

This patient has the characteristic high-pitched, long, blowing diastolic decrescendo murmur of chronic aortic regurgitation. This murmur begins immediately after S2 and is best heard at the mid-left sternal edge. In this example, the S2 is nearly inaudible because it is obscured by the loud murmur. In some patients, the murmur of aortic regurgitation is much softer and can be heard only with the patient seated, leaning forward, and holding the breath at end-expiration. The presence of a wide pulse pressure is also typical of chronic aortic regurgitation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Aortic stenosis: Is a systolic murmur.

 

Option C. Mitral stenosis: Produces a low-frequency diastolic murmur heard best at the apex.

 

Option D. Tricuspid regurgitation: The murmur of tricuspid regurgitation is also heard during systole, and the intensity may increase with inspiration.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman is evaluated for exertional dyspnea. She was previously asymptomatic, but 4 months ago she began having shortness of breath during moderate activity. Blood pressure is 132/80 mm Hg, pulse rate is 80/min, and respiration rate is 22/min. Auscultation is performed at the upper right sternal border. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aortic stenosis

 

Option A:

 

The most likely diagnosis is aortic stenosis. Auscultation reveals a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur at the upper right sternal edge compatible with aortic stenosis. The murmur begins early in systole and extends nearly to S2. The associated carotid pulsation, visually represented by the cotton swab on the carotid artery, may be small in volume and delayed (pulsation occurring slightly after S1).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Mitral regurgitation: Produces a higher-pitched, holosystolic murmur that is loudest at the apex.

 

Option C. Pulmonic stenosis: The murmur of pulmonic stenosis is heard best at the left upper sternal border and may increase in intensity with inspiration.

 

Option D. ventricular septal defect:  A small ventricular septal defect without pulmonary hypertension presents with a loud and often palpable holosystolic murmur located at the left sternal border that may obliterate the S2. Progressive pulmonary hypertension results in shortening of the murmur.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department for an 8-hour history of acute-onset, sharp, and persistent chest pain. Blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 60/min. Auscultation is performed with the diaphragm at the left sternal border. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pericardial rub

 

Option D:

 

The predominant sign of pericarditis is a pericardial friction rub, typically triphasic but possibly present in only one or two phases of the cardiac cycle. Often described as creaking, grating, or scratching, pericardial friction rubs are heard best at the left sternal border with the patient sitting up, leaning forward, and holding the breath in expiration. As in this example, pericardial rubs may vary in intensity with respiration.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aortic regurgitation: Aortic regurgitation is a high-pitched diastolic murmur heard best along the mid-left upper sternal border.

 

Option B. Aortic stenosis: The murmur of aortic stenosis is a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur loudest at the upper right sternal edge.

 

Option C. Patent ductus arteriosus: A continuous murmur of patent ductus arteriosus begins in systole and extends without interruption into diastole.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is evaluated for an 18-month history of progressive fatigue and dyspnea. Blood pressure is 112/72 mm Hg, pulse rate is 76/min, and respiration rate is normal. The apical impulse is slightly sustained but not displaced. Auscultation is performed at the cardiac apex. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mitral stenosis

 

Option C:

 

This patient has the typical findings of mitral stenosis, including a diastolic opening snap followed by a long, low-frequency diastolic murmur best heard at the apex. The murmur peaks during mid-diastole and again before a loud S1. The murmur of mitral stenosis is best appreciated by auscultating with the bell of the stethoscope with the patient in the left lateral decubitus position.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aortic regurgitation:  Aortic regurgitation produces a high-pitched diastolic murmur heard best along the mid left sternal border.

 

Option B. Mitral regurgitation:  Mitral regurgitation produces a high-pitched holosystolic murmur loudest at the cardiac apex.

 

Option D. Pulmonic regurgitation: The murmur of pulmonic regurgitation is early diastolic, best heard over the left second and third interspaces and increases in intensity with inspiration.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman is evaluated for a heart murmur. Blood pressure is 140/70 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 60/min. Auscultation is performed with firm pressure on the diaphragm at the cardiac apex. Which of the following findings accounts for the auscultatory findings at the apex?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mitral regurgitation

 

Option B:

 

This patient has the auscultatory findings of chronic mitral regurgitation, including a high-pitched, blowing holosystolic murmur, ending with S2. This murmur is loudest at the apex. The murmur of chronic mitral regurgitation classically radiates to the left axilla and left scapular area. Although not heard in this clip, an associated S3 may indicate that the regurgitant flow volume is significant or that left heart failure with reduced ejection fraction has developed.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aortic stenosis: Aortic stenosis produces a harsh, systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur that is loudest at the right upper sternal edge.

 

Option C. Mitral stenosis:  The murmur of mitral stenosis is heard during diastole at the cardiac apex. A pericardial friction rub may consist of one to three components and may be heard in systole, diastole, or both systole and diastole.

 

Option D. Tricuspid regurgitation: The holosystolic murmur of tricuspid regurgitation is heard loudest at the lower left sternal edge, and the intensity may increase with inspiration.

questions.text: Loud S1 in mitral stenosis (MS) is lost in all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mild MS

 

Option D:

 

In mild mitral stenosis (MS), the mitral valve leaflets are still relatively mobile and can close forcefully, resulting in a loud S1.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. First-degree heart block: A classic cause of soft S1.

 

Option B. Aortic Regurgitation (AR): Can cause volume overload of the LV and soft S1.

 

Option C. Calcified valve: Calcification of the mitral valve leaflets leads to reduced mobility and a softer S1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitral stenosis is typically associated with a loud S1, this characteristic finding can be lost or diminished in cases of calcified valves.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman came for a routine health check-up. She has no symptoms, and on examination, she has a grade 4/6 holosystolic murmur at the apex. 2D Echo demonstrates severe Mitral regurgitation with LVEF of 50%. The left ventricle is moderately dilated with an LV end-systolic dimension (LVESD) of 42 mm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Surgical mitral valve repair

 

Option B:

 

The patient has severe mitral regurgitation (MR) with left ventricular (LV) dilatation. Although she is currently asymptomatic, the presence of severe MR with EF ≤ 60% and LV enlargement (ESD ≥ 40mm) indicates a high risk of future heart failure and adverse outcomes.

 

Repair is preferred over replacement as it preserves the native valve and avoids the need for long-term anticoagulation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Serial clinical and echocardiographic evaluations: While monitoring is important, it is not the most appropriate next step in this case of severe MR with LV dilatation. Delaying surgery can lead to irreversible LV damage and worsening of symptoms.

 

Option C. Surgical mitral valve replacement: Replacement is considered if repair is not feasible or if the mitral valve is severely damaged. However, repair is the preferred option whenever possible.

 

Option D. Transcatheter mitral valve repair: This is a less invasive option but is currently recommended for patients who are high-risk surgical candidates. This patient is asymptomatic and otherwise healthy, making her a good candidate for surgical repair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Indications for surgical mitral valve repair in asymptomatic patients include severe primary MR and LV dilatation (ESD ≥ 40mm and/or EF ≤ 60%).

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents with recurrent chest pain and dyspnea. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Physical exam reveals elevated JVP, crackles, and a soft early systolic murmur with an S3 gallop. ECG is shown. Chest X-ray shows pulmonary congestion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mitral regurgitation

 

Option C:

 

The patient's presentation is consistent with acute mitral regurgitation (MR) secondary to an inferolateral myocardial infarction (MI). The ECG findings is suggestive of inferior MI with possible posterior MI (see lead V2) and its likely that posteromedial papillary muscle is ruptured in this case (which is supplied by the RCA), leading to Acute MR. The clinical findings of elevated JVP, pulmonary congestion, and an S3 gallop support the diagnosis of acute heart failure, which is a consequence of the severe MR. The soft early systolic murmur and diastolic rumble are also characteristic of MR.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aortic stenosis: While this can cause heart failure, it would present with a harsh systolic murmur radiating to the carotids, not a soft early systolic murmur.

 

Option B. Cardiac tamponade: This can cause elevated JVP and distant heart sounds, but it would not typically present with a new murmur or ECG changes of MI.

 

Option D. Tricuspid regurgitation: This would cause a holosystolic murmur that increases with inspiration, not the early systolic murmur described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute MR usually occurs in association with inferior MI and it is due to rupture of posteromedial papillary muscle.

questions.text: All of the following indicate severe mitral stenosis except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Long A2-OS gap

 

Option C:

 

A2-OS interval is inversely proportional to the severity of mitral stenosis. In severe MS, the left atrial pressure is very high, leading to an early opening snap (OS) and a short A2-OS interval.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Soft S1: In severe MS, the mitral valve leaflets become thickened and calcified, resulting in a softer first heart sound (S1).

 

Option B. Increased duration of MDM: As the severity of mitral stenosis increases, the mid-diastolic murmur (MDM) becomes longer due to the prolonged flow of blood across the narrowed valve.

 

Option D. Palpable P2: In severe MS, pulmonary hypertension often develops, leading to accentuated pulmonary component of the second heart sound (P2), which can be palpable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Short A2-OS gap is a marker of severe mitral stenosis.

questions.text: All of the following are causes of a soft first heart sound except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sepsis

 

Option D:

 

Sepsis is a systemic inflammatory response syndrome that often leads to a hyperdynamic state with increased cardiac output. This results in a louder S1 due to more forceful valve closure.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Calcified valves: Calcification of the mitral valve leaflets can make them rigid and less mobile, leading to a softer S1.

 

Option B. Mitral regurgitation: In some cases of mitral regurgitation, the mitral valve may not close completely, resulting in a softer S1.

 

Option C. Heart failure: Reduced left ventricular contractility in heart failure can lead to less forceful closure of the mitral valve and a softer S1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperdynamic states are associated with loud S1.

choices.text: Esmolol continuous IV infusion titrated to a heart rate of 60–70 beats/min

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman with a history of connective tissue disease presents with acute shortness of breath and pulmonary edema. Examination reveals severe aortic regurgitation due to a right coronary cusp avulsion. She is in cardiogenic shock. What intervention is most likely to maintain end-organ perfusion until surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IV nitroprusside

 

Option C:

 

The patient is experiencing acute, severe aortic regurgitation leading to cardiogenic shock. The goal is to reduce regurgitant blood volume and improve forward flow. Nitroprusside, a vasodilator, decreases systemic vascular resistance (afterload), reducing the pressure gradient driving the regurgitant flow back into the left ventricle.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Esmolol (beta-blocker) continuous IV infusion titrated to a heart rate of 60–70 beats/min: Slowing the heart rate increases diastolic time, worsening regurgitation.

 

Option B. Intra-aortic balloon pump: Contraindicated in severe aortic regurgitation, as it inflates during diastole, further increasing regurgitation.

 

Option D. IV norepinephrine: IV norepinephrine and E. Vasopressin: These are vasopressors that increase afterload, which would worsen aortic regurgitation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In acute severe aortic regurgitation with cardiogenic shock, IV nitroprusside can be used as a bridge to surgery by reducing afterload and improving forward flow.

questions.text: Mrs. Vinitha, a 24-year-old woman with severe mitral stenosis, presents with acute dyspnea and fatigue. On exam, her BP is 110/70 mm Hg and her HR is 50/min. She has bilateral crackles on auscultation. Which of the following interventions would NOT be beneficial?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Transvenous pacemaker placement

 

Option C:

 

The LA to LV pressure gradient is highly dependent on heart rate since diastolic duration is inversely related to heart rate. In the setting of mitral stenosis, a long diastolic time allows more time for the left atrium to empty, and thus lower pressures. Hence, sinus bradycardia is advantageous in the setting of mitral stenosis, and inducing a faster heart rate via pacemaker would be harmful.

 

However, the vast majority of patients with mitral stenosis are unable to maintain sinus rhythm long term as their atria tend to be very dilated. Most develop AF over the course and loss of atrial systole during AF is often poorly tolerated in mitral stenosis.

 

Diuretics and percutaneous mitral valvotomy will lower left atrial pressure.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. IV furosemide: Lowers left atrial pressure and it is beneficial in mitral stenosis.

 

Option B. Percutaneous balloon mitral valvotomy (PBMV): Lowers LA-LV pressure gradient by opening up the stenosed valve and hence it is beneficial in mitral stenosis.

 

Option D. All of the above: This is incorrect, as pacing can be associated with worsening of pulmonary congestion in mitral stenosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Sinus bradycardia is advantageous in the setting of mitral stenosis.

choices.text: MVP is more common in connective tissue diseases such as Marfan syndrome.
MVP occurs more commonly in women than in men.
The anterior leaflet is usually more affected than the posterior leaflet.
The click and murmur of MVP will occur early with the initiation phase of Valsalva.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The anterior leaflet is usually more affected than the posterior leaflet.

 

Explanation:

 

  • In most patients with MVP, the cause is unknown.
  • MVP is a frequent finding in patients with heritable disorders of connective tissue, including Marfan syndrome, osteogenesis imperfecta, and Ehlers- Danlos syndrome.
  • The posterior mitral leaflet is usually more affected than the anterior, and the mitral valve annulus is often dilated.
  • MVP is more common in women and occurs most frequently between the ages of 15 and 30 years; the clinical course is most often benign.
  • A frequent physical examination finding is the mid or late (nonejection) systolic click, followed by a highpitched, mid-late systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur and is heard best at the apex.
  • Radiation of the murmur will depend on the involved leaflet. With posterior leaflet prolapse, the jet of mitral regurgitation (MR) is directed anteriorly and the murmur will radiate to the base of the heart. With anterior leaflet involvement, the jet of MR is directed posteriorly and the murmur will radiate to the axilla and back.
  • The click and murmur occur earlier with standing, during the strain phase of the Valsalva maneuver, and with any intervention that decreases left ventricular (LV) volume (preload), exaggerating the propensity of mitral leaflet prolapse. Conversely, squatting and isometric exercises, which increase LV volume, diminish MVP; the click-murmur omplex is delayed, moves away from S1, and may even disappear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MVP is more common in women and occurs most frequently between the ages of 15 and 30 years; the clinical course is most often benign.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female presented with fatigue. Cardiac catheterization is done and it is demonstrated below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mitral stenosis

 

Option A:

 

The image shows a characteristic pressure tracing of mitral stenosis. The key features that point towards this diagnosis are:

 

Elevated left atrial pressure (LA): The red line (LA pressure) is significantly higher than the left ventricular pressure (LV pressure) during diastole. This indicates a pressure gradient across the mitral valve, suggesting stenosis (narrowing).

 

Diastolic pressure gradient: The shaded area between the LA and LV pressure curves during diastole represents the pressure gradient across the mitral valve. In mitral stenosis, this gradient is elevated.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Aortic stenosis: This would show a pressure gradient between the left ventricle and the aorta during systole.

 

Option C. Mitral regurgitation: This would show a high-pressure V wave in the left atrial pressure tracing during systole, due to blood regurgitating back into the left atrium.

 

Option D. Aortic regurgitation: This would show an elevated left ventricular diastolic pressure and a rapid decline in aortic pressure during diastole.

 

Educational Objective:

 

LA-LV gradient during diastole is characteristic of mitral stenosis.

questions.text: A 44-year-old female presented with palpitations and generalized tiredness. Cardiac catheterization is done, and the results are shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mitral regurgitation

 

Option C:

 

The image shows a cardiac catheterization tracing with a prominent "v wave" in the left atrial (LA) pressure tracing. This v wave is indicative of increased left atrial pressure during systole, which is a hallmark of mitral regurgitation. During systole, blood regurgitates back into the left atrium through the incompetent mitral valve, leading to a rise in LA pressure.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mitral stenosis: In mitral stenosis, there would be a pressure gradient between the left atrium and left ventricle during diastole, leading to an elevated LA pressure throughout diastole, not just during systole.

 

Option B. Aortic stenosis: This would show a pressure gradient between the left ventricle and the aorta during systole.

 

Option D. Aortic regurgitation: This would show an elevated left ventricular diastolic pressure and a rapid decline in aortic pressure during diastole.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Large ‘v’ wave in LA pressure tracing during ventricular systole is characteristic of mitral regurgitation.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presented with chest pain. Cardiac catheterization is done and it is demonstrated below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aortic stenosis

 

Option B:

 

The key finding in the image is a significant pressure gradient between the left ventricle (LV) and the aorta during systole. This pressure gradient indicates that the blood flow from the LV to the aorta is obstructed, which is a hallmark of LVOT obstruction like aortic stenosis. Common symptoms of aortic stenosis include chest pain, syncope and dyspnea (especially during exertion).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mitral stenosis: This would show a pressure gradient between the left atrium and left ventricle during diastole.

 

Option C. Mitral regurgitation: This would show a high-pressure V wave in the left atrial pressure tracing during systole, due to blood regurgitating back into the left atrium.

 

Option D. Aortic regurgitation: This would show an elevated left ventricular diastolic pressure and a rapid decline in aortic pressure during diastole.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pressure gradient between the LV and the aorta during systole is hallmark of LVOT obstruction (like aortic stenosis).

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presented with palpitations and chest pain. Cardiac catheterization is done, and the results are shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aortic regurgitation

 

Option D:

 

The cardiac catheterization tracing demonstrates key findings suggestive of aortic regurgitation:

 

Wide pulse pressure: The aortic pressure tracing shows a high systolic pressure and a significantly lower diastolic pressure, resulting in a wide pulse pressure. This is because a large volume of blood is ejected during systole, but some of it leaks back into the left ventricle during diastole, lowering the diastolic pressure.

 

Rapid decline in aortic diastolic pressure: The aortic pressure tracing shows a steep decline in diastolic pressure. This is indicative of blood flowing back into the left ventricle during diastole.

 

Elevated left ventricular diastolic pressure: The left ventricular pressure tracing shows an elevated diastolic pressure, almost reaching the level of aortic diastolic pressure. This is due to the regurgitant blood flow from the aorta into the LV.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mitral stenosis: This would cause a pressure gradient between the left atrium and left ventricle during diastole, leading to an elevated left atrial pressure.

 

Option B. Aortic stenosis: This would show a pressure gradient between the left ventricle and the aorta during systole, causing the aortic pressure to rise more slowly and not reach as high a peak.

 

Option C. Mitral regurgitation: This would show a prominent V wave in the left atrial pressure tracing during systole, due to blood regurgitating back into the left atrium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low diastolic blood pressure in aorta and elevated LV diastolic pressure are hallmarks of aortic regurgitation.
